headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Shooting in Paris; Rep. Abigail Spanberger is Interviewed about the Spending Bill; Inflation Rose 5.5 percent; Polls on Christmas Favorites. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: We appreciate what you do.

utterances.speaker: SARA SIDNER, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Merry Christmas.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, sir. Merry Christmas.GARETH "OX" LEA, OWNER, OX & SON TOWING: Merry Christmas, guys.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, he's a good guy, man.So -- and that's a tough job.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes, it is.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: New this morning, we are learning of a shooting in Paris that we need to tell you about. We have the details for you. That is next.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And, what we're learning from the just released January 6th committee's final report, ahead.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right, so we have some breaking news to tell you about here. At least three people are dead and four others are injured in central Paris. This after a gunman opened fire this morning.Straight now to Nada Bashir in London. Nada, please inform us. What happened?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Nada, and as you get more information, we'll get back to you.Nada Bashir in London with our breaking news out of Paris this morning. Thank you, Nada.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Now to some other news.On the heels of President Zelenskyy's historic visit to Congress, the House is set to vote on a bill to avoid a government shutdown before funding expires today. The Senate passed its massive $1.7 trillion spending bill on Thursday, which includes roughly $45 billion for Ukraine, funding for prosecutions related to the January 6th attack on the Capitol, and a provision aimed at making it hard to overturn the certified results of a presidential election. Joining us now to discuss is Democratic Congresswoman Abigail Spanberger of Virginia. Thank you so much, Congresswoman, for joining us. REP. ABIGAIL SPANBERGER (D-VA): Thank you for having me.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Let's first talk about this $45 million that has been earmarked for Ukraine, as it's in the midst of fighting -- trying to fight Russia, keeping it from taking over the country and has done an incredibly -- an incredible job at doing that on their own but they are asking for more help. Is this money well worth spent or do you have concerns?

utterances.speaker: SPANBERGER
utterances.sentences: This money is absolutely an investment that the American people are making in supporting our Ukrainian allies, but also in supporting the cause of democracy throughout the world. I think it's important to remember that while we are making substantial investments in Ukraine, we are also leading the way for our allies throughout the world to do the same. We are not alone in providing substantial support, and we have led our partners and allies in the provision of aid, be it lethal aid, humanitarian aid, and also in sanctioning Russian oligarchs and those who are behind and supporting this horrific invasion and war in Ukraine. So I am proud to support this additional provision of aid. It is vitally important that we continue to support the Ukrainian people as they fight for their own democracy and the cause of democracy worldwide. SIDNERto see the work of regular everyday people who do keep saying, look, we just need more weapons, we need more money to try and fight this. But there are those on the other side of the aisle, the Republicans, some of the extreme parts of the party as well saying things like, you know, Zelenskyy is the puppet or the shadow president of the United States, getting all this money. How do you respond to them? And do they have any -- is there anything that you can see there from their side of things that they're worried about things like what's happening at the border and yet spending this kind of money, giving it to Ukraine?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: We can walk and chew gum at the same time.

utterances.speaker: SPANBERGER
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And you were talking about that 4,000 page omnibus bill that I'm sure no one has gotten completely through. But there's also this 845 page final report from the select committee to investigate January 6th. And I do want to ask you lastly about the conclusion, which is that Donald Trump should never be able to hold public office again.Do you agree?

utterances.speaker: SPANBERGER
utterances.sentences: I absolutely agree. It it's why I voted to impeach him when he tried to leverage support for Ukraine and military aid to Ukraine, trying to extort a political favor from President Zelenskyy. It's why I voted to impeach him for inciting an insurrection, as he did on January 6th. And certainly anyone who would stoke that type of violence, lie to the American people over and over and bring about the eventuality that we saw on January 6th and has not backed down from those lies and those incitements to violence ever since should not hold public office ever again.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: All right, Congresswoman Abigail Spanberger, thank you so much. I know that you were put in the position of leadership for the Democrats' battleground leadership and I congratulate you on that and also happy holidays to you.

utterances.speaker: SPANBERGER
utterances.sentences: Happy holidays. Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So, we just got some brand new data in from the Fed's favorite inflation measure for the month of November, and it shows prices moderating for consumers. But the person who can explain this better than any of us is our chief business correspondent Christine Romans.So, what do the numbers show? Good morning, by the way.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CHIEF BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Oh, another little piece of evidence that inflation may have peaked. Prices are moderating for consumers. Prices fell for consumers for gas. Prices, of course. Food prices were up a little bit. But, overall, you're looking at something called the PCE price index, the Fed's favorite inflation gauge grew just 0.1 percent from October to November. That's fine. And year over year up 5.5 percent.In normal times, that 5.5 percent would really freak me out, but that's down from 7 percent just a few months ago. So, you've seen it month after month. If you look at a line chart, you can see the signs of how that appears to be peaking. You see that. So 5.5 percent. We want to see this trend continue, of course. But this is just another little piece of evidence to tuck over there in the inflation is peaking argument camp. And I think that's what you'll be seeing people talk about today, economists talk about today, that this looks like the worst of the inflation, the red hot, 40-year high inflation appears to be behind us.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Looks like. It looks like, yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: It looks like. You know, look, I don't know what's going to happen next year. I mean the forecasts are very, very iffy for the whole next year. But gas prices coming down, consumer confidence went up this week.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: GDP in the third quarter was strong. So, you see these pillars of the economy that seem strong heading into the end of the year. And that strength in the economy, you know, spewed all this inflation.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: And that inflation looks like it's cooling. So -

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right. You never know what's going to happen.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Merry Christmas.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Merry Christmas.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Merry Christmas, you guys.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Merry Christmas.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You look gorgeous. I love the color.

utterances.speaker: ROMANS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It's a Christmas color.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So this morning's number is 79. Harry Enten standing by.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Dionne was the first African American woman to win a Grammy in the pop category.

utterances.speaker: DIONNE WARWICK, MUSICIAN
utterances.sentences: The music I was singing was nothing like anything that any of them were singing.The legacy of my family, music. Pure and simple, music.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Dionne Warwick, "Don't Make Me Over," premieres New Year's Day at 9(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Auntie Warwick has given us life for so, so long. It's going to be good.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I can't wait to see that. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Now, Christmas Eve is tomorrow, as you know, and we're taking a look at all your Christmas favorites from movies to music to food. CNN's senior data reporter Harry Enten is here with us with all of the numbers this morning.All right, we're going to start with Christmas movies. I know I have my favorite. I'll keep it to myself for now. What did you learn?

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: OK, this morning's number is 79. Why? Seventy-nine percent of adults watch Christmas movies to celebrate Christmas. Among those who celebrate Christmas, which is the vast majority of folks. But let's dig into the numbers in terms of your favorite Christmas movie.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: OK, "It's a Wonderful Life" came in at 9 percent.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That's it. That's it.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: We have "The Grinch" at 7 percent. My personal favorite, "Home Alone," at 6 percent.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: And I just wanted to note this because a lot of guys in our crew, "Die Hard" came in at 2 percent. So it - that's a --

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: That's for you, Jake Tapper, right there. It's not a Christmas movie, Jake.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Well, these guys too. It's not -

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It's not a Christmas movie.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's not a Christmas -

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: He said -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: This is it.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, it is.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, wow, did you guys hear that? The voice of God. That's Elie (ph) our - that is -

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: "It's a Wonderful Life."

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And this is all me right here.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I have -

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: "A Christmas Story." I literally --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh. OK, can we roll the tape? I literally went -- there. Look. That is in the place where they shot it in Cleveland. And I could not help myself.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I have no idea what any of that means.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: You don't know what that -- have you not seen "A Christmas Story"?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I - I - I don't really watch -

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I will fight you over that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I like older, traditional movies. I like the black and white old movies. I want to see Scrooge. I want to see "It's a Wonderful Life." I want to see "Rudolph." I don't want to see this new stuff.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I'm giving you straight attitude.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Not interested.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: If you do not - that is not new. It's from 1983, sorry, and it's set back in the '30s or '40s.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Before I was born.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It's new.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I mean - oh, Harry.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That was in 1983. I was in high school. It's new.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: We're not - we're not talking about ages here.How about some - a favorite non-religious Christmas song. "All I Want for Christmas is You," Mariah Carey, 4 percent, "Jingle Bells," 4 percent, "White Christmas," 3 percent, "Chestnuts Roasting on an Open Fire,' the Christmas song, at 2 percent, or "Rudolph the Red Noce Reindeer."

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wait, that - "All I Want for Christmas," I've never heard that song.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: OK, Don, now stop lying.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: All I want for Christmas is you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: No, I'm just joking I love Mariah Carey. Just like I love Whitney Houston. But I used to joke with people saying, "I Will Always Love You," when it come on the radio, I'd say, I've never heard that song, what is it? Because it's always on the radio.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It's always on. Yes, it's true.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Always.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Because it's a number one throughout the year.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: He actually threatened me, when he said, you'd better not say that your favorite is "all I Want for Christmas."

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I love her. I love it.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I do to.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But, just, they play it a lot.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Do you have a favorite Christmas cookie?

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: All of them, basically. Hello.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. That's it. Chocolate chip.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Chocolate chip.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Chocolate chip.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I prefer - I think I'm going to keep it simple with sugar. Just - and one last little thing for you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh, I'm also weird. I also love pound cake. Not pound cake, fruitcake.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Fruit - ew.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And I love chocolate covered cherries.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Wait, pound cake or fruitcake.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Don't stop it. I love chocolate covered cherries and fruitcake.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Artificial trees are where it's at, if you have one at home.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. I agree.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Oh, no. No, no.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I agree with you. I used to love real trees.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Then you've got to gid rid of it. It's way to much.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Oh, (INAUDIBLE).

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: All right, thank Harry and his promo. That's what they're saying.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Harry, thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: OK, so we're also counting down the days until we ring in the new year. Anderson and Andy are back with another global celebration. So, join them for New Year's Eve live from Times Square starting at 8

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Can I - can I show up for that?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Can I just show up and just walk in? Can the bosses hear?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: We got this, though. Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: OK. Ahead, CNN's coverage of the historic storm continues. CNN reporters and government officials are standing by ready to give us the low down.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And that's going to do it for us. So, we're wishing you and your family a very happy holiday from our team here at CNN THIS MORNING.Thank you for joining us this morning.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: It was wonderful. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Merry Christmas to you.
